acf.headline: Low Energy Lighting
acf.summary: Fitting a low energy bulb whenever you change a lightbulb will cut your electricity bill without having any other impact on your household.

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: There are two main types of energy efficient light bulbs available in the UK. Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) and Compact Fluorescent Lamps (CFLs). Both are cost-effective options for most general lighting requirements
steps.read_more:
Replacing a traditional incandescent bulb with an LED or a CFL will save you a few pounds every year for each bulb you change. Replacing all of the bulbs in your house can provide you with some substantial savings on your electricity.
LEDs are more efficient than CFLs and will save you more money in the long term.
They are often used to replace halogen down lighters and other spotlights, but they are now also available as a replacement for most other bulbs as well.

CFLs can be used to replace many old-fashioned bulbs. They are cheap and widely available and what most people know as energy efficient bulbs. If you need a very bright single bulb to light a room, it will be easier to find a CFL to do this rather than an LED.

CFL bulbs do take a little time to reach full brightness.

LED and CFL bulbs will both last a lot longer than an old fashioned filament bulb. They will cost a bit more to buy but, because they last so much longer, you will actually spend less on bulb replacements in the end. And this is on top of the saving you make on your electricity bill.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Energy efficient bulbs are available in a wide range of fittings and outputs. Most households can fit energy efficient lights throughout the whole house. Modern energy efficient bulbs can look and feel exactly like old fashioned bulbs, so there is no reason not to fit them.

steps.headline: Getting the right brightness
steps.description: Finding the right brightness can be a little challenging since the introduction of energy efficient bulbs. Old bulbs were measured in Watts, but this is actually a measure of how much electricity they use, not how much light they give out.
steps.read_more:
Light output is actually measured in lumens (Lm), so all new light bulbs should now have their light output shown in lumens on the packaging. This is the best way to compare the brightness of one bulb with another.

If you are replacing an old bulb, then you won’t know the lumens rating. As a rough guide, you will need about 1,200 to 1,300 Lm to a replace an old 100 watt bulb, and 630 to 700 Lm to replace a 60 watt bulb. You’ll want around 200 to 400 Lm to replace a halogen downlighter.

steps.headline: Getting the right colour
steps.description: Most energy efficient bulbs are available as warm white or cool white.
steps.read_more:
Warm white bulbs give out light that’s the same colour as traditional filament bulbs. If you want to fit energy efficient bulbs without changing the feel of your home, then choose warm white.

Cool white bulbs give out light that is a bit less yellow. The whiter light can create a colder appearance, but some people prefer this.

Some bulbs are also available in a daylight option. These give out pure white light that matches the colour of actual daylight. They are usually used for specific purposes – such as when people need to compare colours accurately as part of their work.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: LEDs and CFLs of various fittings are widely available in DIY or home stores and can also be found in most local supermarkets. You can also find lights for virtually every use by searching online. Make sure you buy the right fitting. When replacing a bulb it is a good idea to take the old bulb to the shop with you, so you can compare fittings.

steps.headline: Using your low energy lighting
steps.description: You can save more money by being conscious about how you use your lighting.
steps.read_more:
• Always turn your lights off when you leave a room, even if just for a minute
• Be conscious of how many lights you have on and whether you need them all on
• Use a sensor to control external lights so they are only on when they need to be
• When the wiring is being done, you should arrange your light switches so that it is convenient to turn them off. For example, at the top and bottom of stairs, each end of a hallway or each door to a room

acf.headline: Take showers instead of baths
acf.summary: Taking a shower instead of a bath is a great way to save money on your energy bills

advantages.advantage: Saves energy and money straight away
No need to buy or fit anything

steps.headline: More details
steps.description: A five minute shower can use about a third of the water of a bath. The less water you use, the less energy you need to heat the hot water, and the lower your energy bills will be. If you have a water meter, you will cut your water bill too. If you have longer showers, then you will use more hot water so your savings will be less. If you want to minimise your energy use, try to keep your showers as short as possible.

steps.headline: Other things you might be interested in
steps.description: See below for other actions you can take to make your showers more efficient.
steps.read_more:
If you have a mixer shower, where the hot water comes from your boiler or hot water cylinder and is mixed with cold at the shower, then you could consider one of these:

• Fitting a water efficient shower head – these can give the same feel as a standard shower head, while using less water, and less energy too.
• Heat recovery system – this is more expensive, and will be easier to fit when you are refurbishing your shower anyway. It recovers heat from the hot water that runs down the drain, and uses it to pre-heat water for the shower, cutting your water heating bills.

If you have an electric shower, with a cold water supply only and an electric switch you can use to turn the shower off, then you can’t fit an efficient shower head or heat recovery system.

• Savings can be even more if you have a water meter or take shorter showers
• Fitting a water efficient shower head will reduce your water usage further

acf.headline: Reduce tumble dryer use
acf.summary: Drying clothes outside when possible and only using the tumble dryer when fully loaded will reduce your energy bills

advantages.advantage: Some clothes will last better if you don’t tumble dry them

steps.headline: More details
steps.description: Tumble dryers use a fair amount of electricity to heat the air they use, as well as to run the fan and motor. If you can dry clothes outside when the weather is dry, you can use the dryer less often and cut your electricity use over the year.  If your washing machine has a fast spin setting, then you can use this to get as much water out of the clothes as possible before you dry them. If you then need to use the dryer, you can run it for a shorter time and still save a bit of energy.

steps.headline: Other things you might want to try
steps.description: When the time comes to buy a new dryer, look at the energy label. The higher the rating, the less energy it will use to dry the same load of washing. The best rating you can now get is A+++.  You can also save energy when you wash your clothes, by waiting until the machine is full before running it, and by washing at a lower temperature when possible. Washing at 30˚C is often enough to get things clean.

acf.headline: Solar electric panels
acf.summary: If you fit electricity generating solar panels to your roof you can cut use some of the generation yourself to cut your bills, and any you don’t use you can feed back to the grid to be used by someone else.

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Solar photovoltaic panels – or PV for short – produce electricity when the sun shines on them. You can use this electricity in the home to run appliances, and any that you don’t use can be sold back to the grid.
steps.read_more:
Solar photovoltaic panels (solar PV) can be mounted on a roof, or any other unshaded spot. When the sun shines on them, they produce low voltage direct current electricity. A device called an inverter converts this into mains voltage alternating current which can be fed directly into your home’s electricity circuit.

If you are at home using electricity at the time, you can use your own solar electricity instead of buying it from your energy supplier. If you aren’t using electricity at the time, your generation will be exported back to the grid to be used by someone else – you can get paid for this if you claim Feed-in Tariff payments.

And If you’re using electricity but the sun isn’t shining, then you just get your electricity from your supplier in the normal way. All this happens automatically – you don’t need to control the panels or the inverter.

Some people also buy a battery system to store electricity when the sun is shining and they’re not at home. They can then use this electricity when they get home, and when the panels are no longer generating. You don’t need to do this to make a solar system work. It doesn’t actually make the system more efficient, but it can increase the amount you save on your electricity bills.

Solar PV panels are completely different to solar water heating panels that use sunlight directly to heat your hot water supply.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you have an area of roof that faces roughly south, and which isn’t often shaded by trees or buildings, then you might want to consider solar PV.
steps.read_more:
Solar PV panels can operate in any light, and facing any direction, but they are more effective if they face towards where the sun is likely to be. Ideally they should be facing south, but anywhere between east and west is worth considering. There is also an optimum angle of elevation (how much they are tilted up) but if you’ve got a sloping roof then that will probably be fine.

The most important thing to avoid is regular shading. If you have somewhere to put the panels where they won’t regularly be shaded by a tree or building, then solar PV is worth considering. It doesn’t have to be a roof, but this is nearly always where people put them.

A typical domestic system might be around 20 square metres. Some are quite a bit smaller, but larger systems tend to be more cost effective.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Solar PV systems should be fitted by a professional installer who is signed up to the Microgeneration Certification Scheme (MCS). You have to use an MCS installer if you want to claim the Feed-in Tariff.

steps.headline: Financial support
steps.description: Solar PV systems can earn money for all the electricity they generate through the Feed-in Tariff.
steps.read_more:
The Feed-in Tariff (FIT) is a scheme that pays money to anyone who generates renewable or low carbon electricity from an eligible system. You can be paid an amount (the generation tariff) for every unit of electricity you generate, whether you use it yourself or sell or feed it back into the grid. You also get paid an extra amount (the export tariff) for every unit you feed back.

The amount you generate in total is measured by a meter fitted as part of the installation. The amount you export is usually assumed to be half the total generation.

To claim the Feed-in Tariff you need to first install an eligible system, and then apply to your electricity supplier. So it’s important you make sure your system is going to be eligible before you go ahead and spend money on it.

steps.headline: Permission
steps.description: You may not need planning permission to fit solar panels to your roof.
steps.read_more:
If you want to fit solar panels in line with your roof, that don’t stick out too much, and you don’t live in a national park, conservation area or listed building, then you may not need planning permission. The rules are complicated, though, so you should check with your local planning office before going ahead.

If you do need planning permission you should wait until it’s granted before you start work or spend any money on the installation.

You will also need permission from the District Network Organisation to connect the system to the grid. Speak to your installer about arranging this, as they will be ensuring that your system meets all the rules for a safe connection.

steps.headline: Using it
steps.description: Once fitted, PV systems will run themselves, but there may be things you want to do to make sure you get the most benefit.
steps.read_more:
A PV system doesn’t need to be controlled. It will generate electricity whenever the sun shines, and this electricity will get used in your home if you need, or will feed into the grid to be used by someone else if you don’t. So you can fit a PV system, forget all about it and carry on as you were. But this might not get you the most out of your system.

PV panels generate during the day, but most of us use electricity mostly in the early morning and in the evening. If you want to make the most of your system you might want to arrange to use your electrical appliances a bit more during the day instead of after it’s dark. This will cut your electricity bill a bit more, making the installation a bit more worthwhile financially.

You can increase the amount you use yourself by fitting a battery store, or by fitting a diverter to heat your hot water whenever you have surplus generation. These systems cost money to install but can make it easier to maximise your savings.

acf.headline: Fit new outside doors
acf.summary: Replacing your outside doors with highly insulated and well draught-proofed doors will help keep your home warm in general, and particularly the room that the door opens into.

advantages.advantage: Opportunity to increase security or improve appearance at the same time

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Replacing your outside doors with highly insulated and well draught-proofed doors will help keep your home warm in general, and particularly the room that the door opens into.
steps.read_more:
Many older external doors fit poorly in their frames, letting cold draughts in. Also, the door itself will often be made of material that lets heat escape even if the draughts are sealed effectively.

A modern, high performance door will fit snuggly and securely in its frame to keep the weather out in general, and the wind in particular. It will also be designed to act as a good insulator, stopping heat escaping through the door itself. The door may be made of wood, metal or PVC, often with insulation built into the structure. It can be partially or fully glazed, in which case this will be double glazed, or even triple glazed.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you have old or poor quality outside doors, then you could benefit from replacing them with something more effective to keep the heat in.
steps.read_more:
If your front door, or any other door that opens to the outside air, doesn’t fit well or is old or made of cheap material, then it could be losing a lot of heat to the outside. You could cut that heat loss significantly by replacing it with a high performance door.

How much difference you notice will depend on how bad your existing door is – you can probably get some idea from how cold the room is, and how much colder it feels when you approach the door.

If you have a porch on the outside of the door, then this will already be helping a bit. You won’t get quite as much benefit from replacing the door, but you will still get some improvement.

Many people will not want to change their doors for energy reasons alone, but if you are thinking it’s time to get a new front door it could be well worth spending a bit more to make sure you get a high performance one.

Internal doors that lead from one room to another are not so important for keeping the heat in. You’ll still want to keep them shut to minimise draughts, especially if one of the rooms isn’t being heated, but there’s no need to replace an internal door with a high performance alternative.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: High performance doors are available online and from some DIY stores, but you will usually want an installer to fit it correctly, and they will usually get the door for you.

steps.headline: Do I need permission?
steps.description: You won’t usually need permission to change your front door unless you live in a conservation area or a listed building. Check with your local planning office to be sure.

acf.headline: Fit secondary glazing
acf.summary: Fitting secondary glazing can cut heat loss through your windows without having to replace them.

advantages.advantage: Can be cheaper than replacing windows

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: You can improve the performance of a window by fitting a secondary glazing layer on the inside – effectively you’re fitting an extra window in the same gap in the wall.
steps.read_more:
If you replace an old window with double glazing, you are cutting heat loss mainly by adding the layer of air that’s trapped between the two panes of glass. You can do much the same thing by leaving the original window in place and fitting an extra pane to the inside. This is called secondary glazing.

There are several ways to go about this, from cheap DIY jobs to more effective, but more expensive, professional installation. Some common approaches are:
• Fitting thin film (a bit like cling film) directly onto the window frame – cheap and easy DIY fix – limited effectiveness and short life.
• Fitting acrylic sheet directly to the frame using a proprietary fixing system – more difficult DIY job – lasts longer than film, and can be removed to open the window and then replaced.
• Professionally fitted openable window, fitted in the window recess – effective, long lasting and neat – more expensive than DIY options.

Secondary glazing cuts heat loss by creating a layer of trapped air. This is different to draught-proofing which stops air blowing through the gaps around the edge of the window. To get the most benefit from secondary glazing, you should draught-proof the existing window first. This way, the trapped air really will be trapped.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Secondary glazing can be effective if you have old windows but you can’t afford to replace them, or you’re not allowed to, or you just don’t want to change the way your house looks from the outside.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Systems to fit yourself can be bought in DIY stores, or online, but for the best performance you will need to pay a professional installer to supply and fit the glazing.

acf.headline: Upgrade double glazing
acf.summary: If you have old or poor quality double glazing, you could make your house warmer by fitting new, higher performance windows.

advantages.advantage: Minimise cold spots around the home
May need to replace damaged or failing windows anyway

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: If you have old or poor quality double glazing, you could make your house warmer by fitting new, higher performance windows.
steps.read_more:
Any double glazed window is likely to be more energy efficient than a single glazed window. But some double glazed windows are better than others, and triple glazed windows can be better still.

Replacing old double glazed windows with new higher performance glazing will cut heat loss through your windows, making the room more comfortable and easier to heat. It can also cut your heating bills slightly.

The energy performance of a new window can be increased in a number of ways, including:
• Coatings on some of the glass surfaces
• Different gases in the gap between the glass
• An extra layer of glass (triple glazing)
• Better design and construction to eliminate draughts
• Better insulation of the frame

Many new windows have an energy label to help you compare their performance without having to worry about all of these elements.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you have double glazed windows that are old or damaged then you might want to consider replacing them.
steps.read_more: It’s difficult to measure how efficient an existing window is, but if the window feels cold then you can probably improve this by fitting an efficient replacement. If the window is obviously damaged, or doesn’t fit properly, or if the glazing unit has misted up on the inside, then it could be time to replace it. You’ll need to replace it sometime soon anyway – if you replace it now then you’ll benefit from a warmer room sooner.

steps.headline: How it might perform
steps.description: Replacing double glazed windows with more efficient glazing can help cut your fuel bills, but the savings will be fairly small and difficult to calculate.
steps.read_more:
The key benefits from fitting new windows will be:
• Increased comfort
• Reduced maintenance
• Adding value to the property

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Windows are normally fitted by a member of a relevant competent person scheme to make sure they comply with Building Regulations. Your installer will usually provide the windows for you.
steps.read_more:
Installers will generally offer you a choice of different styles and layouts of window. Make sure you ask them about the window’s energy rating – it should be somewhere between C and A++.

C is the lowest rating that an installer is generally allowed to fit in a home, and A++ is the highest rating currently available. If you want efficient windows then you should definitely ask for a better rating than C.

If you are offered a window that doesn’t have an energy label, then you don’t really know what you’re buying.

steps.headline: Permission
steps.description: You don’t need planning permission to replace double glazed windows in most homes.
steps.read_more:
if you live in a conservation area or a listed building, then there will be restrictions on what you can and can’t do. But if you already have double glazing then the restrictions may be less rigid, or may not apply. Check with your local planning office before making any decisions.

All window replacement has to comply with the Building Regulations. You can make sure of this by using an installer who is a member of a relevant competent person scheme.

If you are having your windows replaced as part of a bigger refurbishment, your builder may fit the windows themselves and ask the building control officer to approve them. This is fine, but remember to ask your builder to use windows with a high energy rating, rather than using C-rated windows - the minimum allowable.

acf.headline: Fit new double glazed windows
acf.summary: Replacing old single glazed windows with new double glazing will make your home more comfortable and easy to heat.

advantages.advantage: Can deal with draughts from old windows

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Replacing old single glazed windows with new double glazing will make your home more comfortable and easy to heat.
steps.read_more:
Single glazed windows lose a lot of heat to the outside air because the single pane of glass is not a good insulator. If you fit double glazed windows instead, then the air gap between the two panes of glass will insulate your window. This will stop heat escaping so quickly and make your room warmer.

Some double glazed windows have a different gas between the panes of glass, or a special coating on one of the panes. Both of these can insulate the window a bit more. Modern windows also have insulated frames so you don’t lose too much heat around the edges.

Old windows often have gaps around the edges which allow cold draughts to come in, and warm air to escape. If you fit new windows then you will fix this problem too, as well as cutting the heat lost through the glass itself.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you have single glazed windows then it is well worth considering replacing them.
steps.read_more:
If any of the windows in your home have single glazing, then these will be the worst parts of the building in terms of energy performance. They will make your home more expensive to heat, they will make rooms feel cold when you stand near them, and they will attract condensation. And if the windows are old, they’re probably letting in draughts as well.

If you replace them with new double glazed windows then your home will be more comfortable to live in, as well as easier and cheaper to heat.

If you can’t afford to replace the windows right now, then you should check whether they need draught-proofing. This will have less effect than replacing the windows but will be a lot cheaper.

If you are not allowed to replace your windows, you should check the draught-proofing but you might also want to consider fitting secondary glazing.

steps.headline: How do I choose an efficient window?
steps.description: There are quite a few factors that affect the performance of a window, so it’s best to look for the energy label.
steps.read_more:
Many windows have an energy label.
You can use this to compare different windows, and to pick a more efficient option.

You are not normally allowed to fit a window that is worse than a C rating.

If you are offered a window without an energy label, then you don’t really know what you are buying.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Windows are usually supplied and fitted by a professional who will make sure it complies with building regulations.
steps.read_more:
If you are getting your windows replaced, then you should get an approved installer to fit them. The installer should be a member of a competent person scheme for windows. You can find members of a relevant scheme.

The installer will usually supply the windows. When getting quotes, make sure you ask them to give the energy rating for the windows. Some installers may offer you C rated windows to keep the costs down, but you might save more in the long run by opting for a higher rating, even if the windows are more expensive to buy.

steps.headline: Do I need permission?
steps.description: You can replace the windows in most houses without planning permission, but there are restrictions in many areas, and sometimes you may not be allowed to replace them at all.
steps.read_more:
If your house is not listed and is not in a conservation area, then you probably don’t need planning permission to fit new windows. You should check with your local planning office before going ahead though.

If your house is in a conservation area, then there will be rules about what you can and can’t fit. Generally speaking, any new windows will have to look like the original windows, but you will need to check what is acceptable.

If you live in a listed building, then you may not be allowed to replace the windows at all. You may still be allowed to repair them and fit draught-proofing and secondary glazing.

Any new windows that you fit must comply with the building regulations. If you make sure that your installer is a member of a competent person scheme, they will sort this out for you and give you the paperwork to prove it.

acf.is_it_right_for_me: If you have single glazed windows then it is well worth considering replacing them.

acf.headline: Heat recovery system for mixer showers
acf.summary: You can recover and use some of the heat from the hot water that runs down the drain whenever you have a shower.

advantages.advantage: Once fitted, you won’t know it’s there

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: You can recover and use some of the heat from the hot water that runs down the drain whenever you have a shower.
steps.read_more: Whenever you have a shower, all the hot water you use runs down the drain almost immediately, taking all that valuable heat with it. A heat recovery system can take some of that heat and use it to pre-heat the shower water. So your boiler doesn’t have to work so hard to heat your shower water, and you use less fuel.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Heat recovery devices can be fitted to many mixer showers, but they are easiest to fit when you’re fitting a new shower, or doing other major work in the bathroom. They don’t work with electric showers.
steps.read_more:
A mixer shower is one where you have both hot and cold water pipes running to the shower. You use the taps to mix them together in the shower to get the temperature you want. The hot water will come from your hot water cylinder, or directly from your boiler if you have a combi.

If you have this type of shower, you may well be able to fit a heat recovery system.

The other common type of shower is an electric shower. You’ll have just one cold pipe feeding the shower, and an electric switch somewhere to turn the shower on and off. If you have this type of shower, you can’t fit a heat recovery system.

Heat recovery is more likely to be cost effective if you install it when you are fitting a new shower, or re-fitting an old one. It’s also more likely to make sense in a home that uses the shower a lot – for example, where there’s a large family and only one shower.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Fitting a heat recovery system is not a DIY job. You should use a certified installer to supply and fit a system for you.

acf.headline: Solar water heating
acf.summary: Solar water heating panels provide hot water for your taps and showers when the sun shines

advantages.advantage: Cuts your carbon emissions and fuel bills
May get financial help from the RHI

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Solar water heating panels provide hot water for your taps and showers when the sun shines
steps.read_more:
Solar water heating panels are usually fitted to your roof and connected to your hot water cylinder, or to a new hot water cylinder. When the sun shines they heat water in the panel, which is pumped round a circuit of pipes. Heat from the pipes is used to heat the water in the hot water cylinder. Sometimes this is enough on its own to get the hot water up to temperature – at other times you will still need your boiler or electric immersion heater to get the water fully hot.

There are two common types of solar water heating panel:

Flat plat collectors are the simpler technology – they’re cheaper per square metre, but you need more to get the same amount of heat.

Evacuated tubes are more high tech – they’re handy if you only have room for a small panel, but you’ll pay just as much for the same output.

Most solar water heating systems are designed to provide about half your hot water demand from the sun, whichever technology you use, with the rest coming from your existing boiler or immersion heater. They are not normally designed to provide any space heating, as they provide most output at times when space heating isn’t needed.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Solar water heating is usually installed in homes with a regular boiler and hot water cylinder. It can be possible to fit solar water heating with a combi boiler, but this is not always straightforward – ask an installer for advice on this.
steps.read_more:
You will also need an area of roof facing roughly south – anywhere between east and west is possible – that isn’t often shaded. Ideally this roof area should be quite close to your hot water cylinder to keep pipework to a minimum.

Some households don’t spend all that much money on hot water, and so they can’t save a huge amount either. Solar water heating is most likely to be financially attractive in a home that uses a lot of hot water (a large family, for example) and that uses an expensive fuel (such as electricity) to heat the water.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: You will need a certified installer to fit solar water heating. They must be certified by the Microgeneration Certification Scheme if you want to claim RHI payments.

steps.headline: Financial support
steps.description: The RHI can pay you for the amount of useful hot water your solar panels are expected to produce, every three months for seven years.
steps.read_more:
If you install a solar water heating system that meets all the requirements of the RHI, then you can claim support for the first seven years that you use it to provide hot water.

• They provide heat for domestic hot water only (not space heating)
• They are installed in an existing house or a self-build
• The panels are an approved model
• The installer is registered with the Microgeneration Certification Scheme

steps.description: You may not need planning permission to fit solar panels to your roof.
steps.read_more:
If you want to fit solar panels in line with your roof, that don’t stick out too much, and you don’t live in a national park, conservation area or listed building, then you may not need planning permission. The rules are complicated, though, so you should check with your local planning office before going ahead.

If you do need planning permission you should wait until it’s granted before you start work or spend any money on the installation.

acf.headline: Ground source heat pump
acf.summary: Takes heat from the ground and upgrades it to a higher temperature so it can be used to heat your home.

advantages.advantage: RHI payments can result in good payback

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: A ground source heat pump takes heat at a low temperature from the ground outside your house. It then uses an electric compressor system to increase the temperature of this heat, so it can be used to provide space heating and hot water for your home.
steps.read_more:
Left to its own devices, heat will normally flow from a hot place to anywhere that is colder. A heat pump is an appliance that makes heat flow in the opposite direction – it “pumps” the heat from a cold place to somewhere that is warmer.

A ground source heat pump takes heat from the ground and transfers it to a working fluid. It does this either through a horizontal loop of pipework buried beneath the ground (a ground loop) or from holes drilled vertically into the ground (a borehole). The heat pump then uses a compressor to change the pressure and temperature of the fluid until it is warm enough to provide heating for the house.

The heat pump uses electricity, so it is not free to use and it is not zero carbon. But some of the heat it produces comes from the ground, not from the electricity, so it gives out more energy as heat than it uses as electricity. If it runs efficiently, a heat pump can be cheap to run and can be a low carbon heating option for your home.

Heat pumps are more efficient when they give out heat at a relatively low temperature. They are often used with underfloor heating, as this can operate successfully at low temperatures, but they can be used with conventional radiators.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Ground source heat pumps require either a large garden or similar area for a ground loop, or a smaller area with access for drilling equipment, for a borehole. They are most likely to be attractive in homes that are well insulated, and where other heating options like gas are not available.
steps.read_more:
Heat pumps are more efficient when they don’t have to raise the temperature of the heat they extract too much. This means they are more efficient when they can run a heating circuit at a lower temperature. If your home is well insulated then it needs less heat to keep it warm. You can run your radiators or underfloor heating at a lower temperature and still keep your home at the temperature you want.

If you live in a fairly new house, or if you already have underfloor heating, then you could be well suited to a heat pump. If not, you may want to look at increasing your insulation levels or changing your radiators.

If you live somewhere where electric heating is the only option, then a heat pump is likely to be cheaper to run than other systems.

If your house is suited to a heat pump but you don’t have space for a ground loop or borehole, then you might want to consider an air source heat pump instead.
This may not achieve the same efficiency all year round, but it will usually be cheaper to install.

steps.headline: How it might perform
steps.description: A well designed heat pump system, fitted in an appropriate house and operated correctly, can produce more than three times as much heat as it uses electricity. This could keep your heating bills low as well as helping to reduce your carbon footprint.
steps.read_more:
A heat pump uses electricity to run and it produces heat, just like an electric heater. But unlike an electric heater it produces more heat than it uses electricity. For every unit of electricity used it could produce two or three units of heat. The number of units of heat produced for each unit of electricity is known as the Coefficient of Performance, and the average Coefficient of Performance over a typical year is known as the Seasonal Coefficient of Performance (SCoP), or Seasonal Performance Factor.

Any decent heat pump system should have a SCoP of more than 2, and a good system could operate at more than 3 – that is, it would produce more than three units of heat for every unit of electricity used. This would make it one of the cheapest heating systems to operate, as well as one of the greenest.

We have estimated the running costs and savings for your situation based on the information you have provided. If you ask an installer to quote for a system they will carry out an assessment based on the characteristics of your home and the system they are proposing, and will give you a more accurate estimate of the likely performance.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Specifying a heat pump system is a specialist job. You should use a registered heat pump installer to oversee all the design and installation work, including specifying the ground loop or borehole.

steps.headline: Financial help
steps.description: If you install an eligible ground source heat pump you may be able to claim payments from the Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI)
steps.read_more:
The Domestic Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) provides financial support to householders who install certain renewable heating systems in their home. If eligible, you could receive quarterly payments for a period of seven years, based on the amount of renewable heat you are expected to use.

Ground source heat pumps can be eligible provided:
• They provide heat through the medium of hot water (e.g. radiators or underfloor heating)
• They are installed in an existing house or a self-build
• The heat pump is an approved model
• The installer is registered with the Microgeneration Certification Scheme
The system is designed to operate efficiently (with a Seasonal performance Factor of at least 2.5)

You will need to install your heat pump before you apply for the RHI, but you may want to check the eligibility criteria first to see if you are likely to qualify for help.

steps.headline: Permission
steps.description: Ground source heat pumps can often be installed without planning permission, but the rules are quite complex. You should check with your local planning authority before going ahead.
steps.read_more: Some borehole heat pumps are open loop – that is, they extract water from the ground and then return it. You will need an abstraction license from the Environment Agency to install an open loop heat pump system. Speak to your installer about how to do this.

steps.headline: Using it
steps.description: A heat pump can keep your home comfortable and your water hot, while keeping your bills and your carbon emissions down, but you will need to use the system in the recommended way to make the most of these benefits.
steps.read_more:
If you have gas central heating, then you probably set it to come on about half an hour before you get up in the morning. The boiler will run at full blast for that half an hour to make sure your home is warm when you get out of bed. This works well because a gas boiler is very efficient when working at full output.

Heat pumps are at their most efficient when running steadily and producing heat at low temperature. To make the most of your heat pump you will need to programme it so that it can run for longer than a gas boiler, but at lower output. This may mean you leave the heating on for periods when you would turn it off if you had gas heating. You may also need to accept that it will be difficult to heat the house up quickly from cold just using the heat pump.

Your installer will advise you on how to set your heating controls. You should follow this advice to avoid getting unnecessarily high heating bills.

acf.headline: High heat retention storage heaters
acf.summary: Modern storage heaters are better insulated, so more of the heat they store at night is available for use during the day.

advantages.advantage: Straightforward replacement for old storage heaters
No need for gas supply or radiator plumbing

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Modern storage heaters are better insulated, so more of the heat they store at night is available for use during the day.
steps.read_more:
A storage heater works by using electricity at night, when it is cheap, to heat up the inside of the heater. You can then open flaps to let the heat out the next day and into the evening, so you get heating when you want it instead of just when electricity is cheap.

Storage heaters are insulated to try and stop the heat escaping before you want it. With older heaters this insulation may be less than ideal, so there is more of a chance you will run out of heat the next evening. A modern high heat retention storage heater has better insulation, so it will give off less heat when you don’t want it, leaving more in store for when you do.

It will also be fitted with fans to blow hot air out into the room when you want. This makes an even bigger difference between the heat given out when you want it and the heat given out when you don’t.

Modern storage heaters generally come with more advanced controls, so you just set the temperature you want and the control system does the rest.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you already have storage heaters, or any other form of electric heating, then replacing them with high heat retention storage heaters could cut your electricity bill and may make your heating more controllable.
steps.read_more:
If you have old storage heaters, then you probably find them difficult to control and you may find they heat the house whether you want them to or not. Replacing them with high heat retention models is the simplest way to cut your electricity use and your bills, and you should find it easier to get heat when you want it, and to turn it off when you don’t.

If you have an electric boiler with a large heat store, then you already have a highly controllable system that runs on off-peak electricity. These are not common in the UK but, if you’ve got one, there’s no point in replacing it with any type of storage heater.

If you use any other type of electric heating as your main heat source, then it will not be able to make the best use of an off-peak tariff. You may want to consider fitting high heat retention storage heaters so you can heat your home entirely with cheaper rate electricity.

If you want to switch to something greener than electricity for heating, then you could consider one of these:
• air source heat pump - more info
• ground source heat pump – more info
• wood boiler – more info
• micro CHP - more info

All of these will cost more to install than storage heaters, but they can reduce your greenhouse gas emissions, and you could get financial help from the Renewable Heat Incentive or Feed-in Tariff.

If there is gas available at your home, or close by, you might want to consider fitting a gas central heating system to keep your running costs to a minimum.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: You will need a certified electrician to fit new storage heaters and controls, and they will usually provide the heaters for you.

steps.headline: Do I need permission?
steps.description: You don’t normally need planning permission to fit a storage heater. Your certified installer will ensure your system complies with the requirements for electrical installations.

steps.headline: Living with your new storage heaters
steps.description: Your new heater controls should be much easier to operate than old fashioned storage heater controls, but they are different so you should familiarise yourself with them.
steps.read_more:
Modern storage heaters are likely to have a thermostatic control for each heater. You should set this to the temperature you want for the room and leave the heater to do the rest. If you can turn it down slightly lower and still feel comfortable, then this could your bills quite a bit.

You can turn the thermostat right down when you don’t want to heat the room. But don’t turn it right up to full when you want the heating back on – just turn it back up to the level you decided was acceptable before. The room will heat up just as quickly, but without getting too hot and wasting energy and money.

acf.headline: Wood pellets boiler
acf.summary: Wood pellets are the easiest form of wood fuel to use, and can be used to run a central heating system much like a conventional gas or oil boiler.

advantages.advantage: Can be financially attractive with RHI payments

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Wood pellet boilers can feed fuel into the burner automatically, and so can run a central heating system in much the same way as a gas or oil boiler, with very little input from the householder.
steps.read_more:
Wood pellets are made from compressed sawdust. Unlike other types of wood fuel they can be moved by machinery, so pellet boilers can operate automatically without the need for the householder to feed the fuel by hand. If you have enough room you can fit a large fuel store and have bulk deliveries by lorry, so you don’t have to handle the fuel at all. Otherwise you can save space, buy the fuel in bags and feed the fuel in a bag at a time.

The boiler provides hot water which can be used to heat the radiators and hot water cylinder, just like a regular central heating system. You can control the system with standard heating controls such as a programmable thermostat.

Pellets can be bought from registered suppliers who guarantee to provide only fuel from sustainable sources. Provided the fuel source is sustainable, wood is a very low carbon fuel.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Wood pellet heating can give you very low carbon heating while still offering you mostly automatic operation, but you will need space to fit the boiler and store the fuel.
steps.read_more:
Pellet boilers are larger and heavier than an equivalent gas or oil boiler, so you will need somewhere to fit it and access to get it in there. You will also need somewhere to store some fuel – at least a corner to stack a few bags, but you’ll need a whole shed or small garage if you want to fit a bulk store.

Pellet boilers can mostly operate automatically, but they do require some input from you, especially if you opt for bagged fuel.

You cannot make your own wood pellets. If you have access to wood that you want to burn as fuel you should consider a log boiler, or one or more log stoves.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Pellet boilers should be installed by a qualified professional. Usually the installer will choose and supply the boiler.
steps.read_more: Wood boiler installations need to conform to building regulations. The easiest way to ensure this is to make sure your installer is a member of a relevant competent person scheme.

steps.headline: Financial help
steps.description: The RHI can pay you for the amount of heat your pellet boiler is expected to produce, every three months for seven years.
steps.read_more:
If you install a wood pellet boiler that meets all the requirements of the RHI, then you can claim support for the first seven years that you use the boiler to heat your home.

Pellet boilers can be eligible provided:
• They provide heat through the medium of hot water (e.g. radiators or underfloor heating)
• They are installed in an existing house or a self-build
• The boiler is an approved model
• The installer is registered with the Microgeneration Certification Scheme
• The fuel is bought from a registered supplier

You will need to install your heat pump before you apply for the RHI, but you may want to check the eligibility criteria first to see if you are likely to qualify for help.

steps.headline: Do I need permission?
steps.description: Pellet boilers are generally installed indoors, and so will usually not require planning permission. However, if you need to build a structure to house the boiler or fuel store, or you need to fit an external flue, then it is possible you will need permission, particularly if your house is in a conservation area. If in any doubt, you should check with your local planning authority before going ahead.
steps.read_more:
All wood heating systems have to comply with the building regulations. The easiest way to do this is to use an installer who is a member of a relevant Competent Person Scheme – see How do I get it?

If you live in a Smoke Control Zone you should make sure that the boiler you are installing is an exempt appliance – if in doubt, check with your installer.

steps.headline: Living with a pellet boiler
steps.description: Pellet boilers can run largely automatically, but will still require some input from you.
steps.read_more:
A pellet boiler feeds fuel to the burner automatically as required. This means it can run a central heating system using exactly the same controls as a gas boiler system. You don’t need to add more fuel to make the heating hotter.

If you have a bulk fuel store, then you can get this filled by tanker, and the system will feed the pellets from the store to the boiler whenever required. So you never have to handle any wood fuel. You will still have to order deliveries of wood from time to time to avoid running out.

If you don’t have a bulk store, then you will need to buy fuel in bags. Whenever the hopper in the boiler runs low you will need to get another bag and pour it into the hopper to keep your system working.

A pellet boiler produces a lot less ash than a coal fire, but it still produces some ash. You will need to empty this ash out from time to time – how often will depend on the design of your boiler.

acf.headline: Flue gas heat recovery
acf.summary: This device uses heat from your boiler flue and recycles it to cut your water heating bills

advantages.advantage: Fit and forget – no need to control it
No impact on your heating or hot water supply
Cheaper if fitted at the same time as a new boiler
One way to meet new building regulations in England

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: A flue gas heat recovery system uses some of the heat from your boiler’s flue gases and uses it to help heat your hot water.
steps.read_more:
When your boiler is operating to run your central heating, some of the heat it produces is lost through the hot flue gases escaping to the outside air. If you are using hot water at the same time, a flue gas heat recovery system can recover some of this heat and use it to pre-heat your hot water supply, saving a bit more gas.

Some systems include a small heat storage tank, so they work even if you use hot water at slightly different time to when you are using the heating.

A flue gas heating system fixes directly onto the boiler. It can be possible to fit one to an existing boiler, but it is more common to buy one when you are fitting a new boiler.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Flue gas heat recovery devices are suitable for condensing combi boilers only.
steps.read_more:
If you are replacing your gas boiler, and you have opted to go for a combi model (one that heats the hot water on demand instead of heating a separate hot water cylinder) then you could have a flue gas heat recovery system fitted along with the boiler. Sometimes the heat recovery device is supplied as a separate unit, and sometimes the boiler is supplied with the heat recovery system incorporated.

If you already have a condensing combi boiler, it may be possible to buy a new heat recovery device and have it fitted to your existing boiler.

If you have a regular or system boiler, with a separate hot water cylinder, then you cannot have a flue gas heat recovery device. You could consider solar water heating instead.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Your flue gas heat recovery device will be provided by your boiler installer.
steps.read_more:
Any work carried out on a gas boiler must be carried out by a registered gas installer, and they will choose and supply an appropriate heat recovery device for your boiler.

If you want to check if you can have heat recovery added to your existing boiler, you should ask a registered installer for advice.

steps.headline: Other things you may want to know
steps.description: Fitting a flue gas heat recovery can help you meet building control requirements when you fit a new boiler.
steps.read_more:
If you live in England, and you have a new gas combi boiler fitted, your installer may need to upgrade your systems to comply with new regulations.

Fitting flue gas heat recovery is one option to meet this requirement.

The others are all heating control options – weather compensation, load compensation, and smart control with automation and optimisation. You can read more about these options here.

acf.headline: Switch to gas central heating
acf.summary: Fitting new gas central heating is quite a job, but it will cut your heating costs significantly.

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Gas central heating with a modern efficient boiler and controls is one of the cheapest ways to heat a home.
steps.read_more:
Most homes in Britain have gas central heating. A boiler runs on mains gas, providing hot water that is used to heat radiators and to provide hot water for your taps. There are controls you can set to decide when the heating comes on and turns off, and what temperature the house should be heated to.

Modern boilers are very efficient, and modern controls allow you to run the boiler only as much as you need to. This can make gas central heating one of the cheapest systems to run. It’s also quite low in carbon emissions compared to many other systems like electric heaters.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you have a gas supply to your house, or if it’s available close by, then gas central heating is certainly something you should consider.
steps.read_more:
It’s quite an upheaval having all the radiators fitted if you don’t already have them. But once they’re in they will last for years with minimal maintenance. It will cost quite a bit to fit all this and the boiler, but you will end up with a system that’s relatively cheap to run and easy to control.

If you want to keep your carbon emissions to an absolute minimum then you might want to think about a low carbon heating system, like a heat pump or wood boiler instead.

steps.headline: Different types of boiler
steps.description: All new boilers are condensing boilers - this just means they are more efficient than older boilers. But there are two main types of condensing gas boiler, those with a hot water cylinder and those without.
steps.read_more:
Combi boilers provide hot water on demand. Whenever you turn a hot tap on, the boiler fires up, and starts heating the water supply to the tap. There is no hot water cylinder.

Regular boilers provide hot water by heating a separate hot water cylinder. When you turn on a hot tap, the hot water comes directly from the cylinder.

There is a third type, known as a system boiler. This has some of the elements of a combi boiler, making it easier to install, but it provides hot water via a cylinder, just like a regular boiler.

steps.headline: How to get it

acf.headline: New condensing gas boiler (no fuel switch)
acf.summary: Replacing your gas boiler with a more efficient model can cut your heating bills significantly.

advantages.advantage: Cheaper than many other heating systems

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: A condensing boiler is just a name for a modern, efficient boiler that turns more of the heat it produces into hot water for your radiators and taps.
steps.read_more:
When a boiler burns gas, it converts most of that heat into hot water which is then used to heat your radiators, and to provide hot water for your taps. The rest of the heat disappears up the flue as hot gases, and is wasted.

A modern efficient boiler uses a bigger heat exchanger to convert more of the heat to hot water, so less heat is wasted in the flue gases. This makes it more efficient, so you burn less gas to heat your home, and you save money.

Sometimes the flue gases are cooled so much that water vapour condenses, producing a visible white plume. This is why modern boilers are called condensing boilers.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you have a gas boiler that was fitted before 2005, then the chances are that it is an inefficient boiler. If this is the case, then you could cut your heating bills significantly by replacing it with a modern efficient model.
steps.read_more:
There are a few things you can do to check if your existing boiler is a condensing model:
• If there is a pipe running from the boiler to an outside drain, then it is a condensing model – if not, it isn’t
• If the flue is made of plastic, then it’s condensing – if not, it probably isn’t
• If you can see clouds of white “steam” coming out of the flue in cold weather, then it’s a condensing model – if it’s not condensing, you’ll hardly ever see this.

If you’re going to replace your boiler, but you want to go for something greener than gas, then you could consider one of these:
• air source heat pump - more info
• ground source heat pump – more info
• wood boiler – more info
• micro CHP - more info

All of these will cost more to install than a gas boiler, but they can reduce your greenhouse gas emissions, and you could get financial help from the Renewable Heat Incentive or Feed-in Tariff.

steps.headline: Different types of condensing boiler
steps.description: There are two main types of gas boiler – those with a hot water cylinder and those without.
steps.read_more:
Combi boilers provide hot water on demand. Whenever you turn a hot tap on, the boiler fires up, and starts heating the water supply to the tap. There is no hot water cylinder.

Regular boilers provide hot water by heating a separate hot water cylinder. When you turn on a hot tap, the hot water comes directly from the cylinder.

There is a third type, known as a system boiler. This has some of the elements of a combi boiler, making it easier to install, but it provides hot water via a cylinder, just like a regular boiler.

steps.headline: Living with your new boiler
steps.description: Your new boiler should work just like your old one, only better, but there are things you can do to make the most of the benefits.
steps.read_more:
Your new condensing boiler should operate much like your old one, so you shouldn’t notice any difference other than lower gas bills. However, the new boiler may give out more heat, or operate at a different temperature. You should check that you’re using your heating controls effectively, otherwise you might not get the maximum benefit from your new boiler.

Your installer may fit new heating controls when they fit the boiler, particularly if your old controls don’t meet the current standards. Make sure your installer explains what the new controls are and how you should use them.

acf.headline: Fit new heating controls
acf.summary: Upgrading your heating controls could help you save money, while also making sure that your home is always comfortable.

advantages.advantage: Range of options to suit different households
Can cut your heating bills significantly
Helps to keep your home at a comfortable temperature

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Upgrading your heating controls could help you save money, while also making sure that your home is always comfortable.
steps.read_more:
All heating control systems essentially do two things – they control when you want the heating on, and how warm you want your home to get when the heating is on. They may also do the same for your hot water.

There are lots of types of controls available to do this, but a fully controlled heating system should include at least:
• A timer or programmer function – this sets the time for when the heating comes on and when it goes off
• A central thermostat – this sets the temperature for the home, and turns the heating off when it gets warmer than this
• Thermostatic radiator valves – these are fitted to most of the radiators, and they control the temperature in each room

Sometimes the programmer and central thermostat are combined in one unit – a programmable thermostat. You can use this to set different temperatures for different times of day.

You can also add other control functions– click here for information on more advanced heating controls.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you can’t control the time your heating turns on or off, and the temperature throughout the house, then you should consider fitting new heating controls.
steps.read_more:
For any central heating system, you shouldbe able to control:
• When the heating turns on and off
• What temperature the home in general should be at
• What temperature each room should be at

If you can’t do all of these with your current controls, then you should look at upgrading them.

If you live in England and you're getting a new boiler fitted, then you will need to meet new standards for heating controls at the same time, and so you may have to upgrade.

If you're having any other work carried out on your heating system, this is the perfect time to consider upgrading your controls. It's often easier and cheaper to have different improvements fitted at the same time.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: You will generally need to get your heating engineer to fit new controls for you, and they will usually supply the controls themselves.

steps.headline: Using it
steps.description: Make sure you understand how your new controls work, so that you can use them to save money and stay warm.
steps.read_more:
Every heating control system looks different, and has a different selection of buttons and dials, but they’re all trying to do the same thing. There are two things you need to do:
• Work out your strategy for keeping warm without wasting fuel
• Understand how the heating controls in your house can make this happen

Generally, your strategy should be to set thermostats so that you are warm enough, but not too warm, when the heating is on. You should set your programmer so that your heating comes on shortly before you get up or come home, and goes off shortly before you go out or go to bed.

If everyone is out during the day, then the heating should be off for this time. If you're at home during the day, you may find you're comfortable with a lower temperature at this time.

If there is anyone at home who is old or infirm, you may need to keep the thermostat a little higher.

Click here to see our video on how to control your heating.

We also have videos on using particular types of heating control here.

Make sure you ask your installer how to use the controls – they should be happy to do this, as well as giving you the instruction manuals.

acf.headline: Hot water cylinder thermostat
acf.summary: Fitting a hot water cylinder thermostat will help keep your hot water at the right temperature and avoid wasting energy keeping it hotter than you need.

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Fitting a hot water cylinder thermostat will help keep your hot water at the right temperature and avoid wasting energy keeping it hotter than you need.
steps.read_more:
The thermostat is fitted onto the side of your hot water cylinder, and it has a dial to set the temperature you want.

Whenever your hot water is turned on, your heating system will use the thermostat to decide whether your cylinder needs to be heated up or not. If you set the thermostat slightly lower, then the water heating will come on less often and you will use less fuel.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you have a hot water cylinder and it doesn’t have a thermostat, then you should get one fitted.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Most plumbers can fit a thermostat for you. If your water is heated by electric immersion heater, then an electrician could fit it.

steps.headline: Using it
steps.description: A hot water cylinder thermostat should usually be set to 60˚C. Any hotter and you will be wasting energy heating your water to a temperature you don’t need. Any colder and there is a risk that harmful bacteria could grow in your hot water cylinder over time.
steps.read_more: Water at 60˚C is too hot for most household uses, so you’ll usually still want to mix it with cold. If you are concerned about having hot taps that are too hot for some people in the house, you can fit thermostatic mixers to each tap to reduce the temperature. You shouldn’t turn the cylinder thermostat down to avoid having scalding hot water.

acf.headline: Hot water cylinder insulation
acf.summary: You need good insulation on your hot water cylinder so your water stays hot and you don’t waste money heating it up twice.

steps.headline: What is it
steps.description: You need good insulation on your hot water cylinder so your water stays hot and you don’t waste money heating it up twice.
steps.read_more:
Hot water cylinders are heated up at certain times of day, and then used whenever you run a hot tap. You need a good level of insulation to keep as much of the heat in the cylinder as possible, so that it is still hot when you want to use it, and so that your boiler or immersion heater doesn’t have to keep switching back on to re-heat the water.

Some cylinders are covered in rigid insulation foam, or they may have a separate insulation cover known as a tank jacket. To be effective, you need to make sure your insulation is thick enough – 80mm (three inches) is recommended. And if you have a tank jacket, you need to make sure it fits well and is secured properly, with no gaps that can let the heat escape.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If you have a hot water cylinder, and it has less than 80mm (3 inches) of insulation, then you should consider adding some more.
steps.read_more:
If your hot water system includes a hot water cylinder, then you need to make sure it is adequately insulated. The cylinder itself may have been built without insulation, or it may have been coated in spray foam before it left the factory. There may be a separate insulating jacket instead, or possibly as well as the spray foam.

Many insulated cylinders only have about 25mm (one inch) of insulation. If you have a pre-insulated cylinder, you can usually see how thick the insulation is at some point where there is a gap to fit a thermostat or immersion heater.

If you only have 25mm of insulation, then you should fit a tank jacket (or a second jacket) to get you up to the recommended 80mm.

If you have a cylinder with no insulation, then you should insulate as a priority – you’re wasting a lot of money heating up water that cools down before you get the chance to use it.

If you have a combi boiler that heats up your hot water on demand, then you won’t have a hot water cylinder and you don’t need any cylinder insulation.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Insulation jackets can be bought in any DIY store, and are very easy to fit in most cases. You can’t add spray foam to an existing cylinder, though you could ask a heating engineer to fit a new, well insulated cylinder if you are making changes to your system.

steps.headline: Will it make my airing cupboard cold?
steps.description: No amount of insulation will stop the heat escaping entirely, so your airing cupboard should still be warm enough to air clothes.

steps.headline: Other things you may want to know
steps.description: While you’re checking your tank insulation you should also check that your hot pipes are insulated, especially the one coming out of the top of the cylinder (link to pipe insulation)

acf.headline: Low Energy Lighting
acf.summary: Fitting a low energy bulb whenever you change a lightbulb will cut your electricity bill without having any other impact on your household.

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: There are two main types of energy efficient light bulbs available in the UK. Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) and Compact Fluorescent Lamps (CFLs). Both are cost-effective options for most general lighting requirements
steps.read_more:
Replacing a traditional incandescent bulb with an LED or a CFL will save you a few pounds every year for each bulb you change. Replacing all of the bulbs in your house can provide you with some substantial savings on your electricity.
LEDs are more efficient than CFLs and will save you more money in the long term.
They are often used to replace halogen down lighters and other spotlights, but they are now also available as a replacement for most other bulbs as well.

CFLs can be used to replace many old-fashioned bulbs. They are cheap and widely available and what most people know as energy efficient bulbs. If you need a very bright single bulb to light a room, it will be easier to find a CFL to do this rather than an LED.

CFL bulbs do take a little time to reach full brightness.

LED and CFL bulbs will both last a lot longer than an old fashioned filament bulb. They will cost a bit more to buy but, because they last so much longer, you will actually spend less on bulb replacements in the end. And this is on top of the saving you make on your electricity bill.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Energy efficient bulbs are available in a wide range of fittings and outputs. Most households can fit energy efficient lights throughout the whole house. Modern energy efficient bulbs can look and feel exactly like old fashioned bulbs, so there is no reason not to fit them.

steps.headline: Getting the right brightness
steps.description: Finding the right brightness can be a little challenging since the introduction of energy efficient bulbs. Old bulbs were measured in Watts, but this is actually a measure of how much electricity they use, not how much light they give out.
steps.read_more:
Light output is actually measured in lumens (Lm), so all new light bulbs should now have their light output shown in lumens on the packaging. This is the best way to compare the brightness of one bulb with another.

If you are replacing an old bulb, then you won’t know the lumens rating. As a rough guide, you will need about 1,200 to 1,300 Lm to a replace an old 100 watt bulb, and 630 to 700 Lm to replace a 60 watt bulb. You’ll want around 200 to 400 Lm to replace a halogen downlighter.

steps.headline: Getting the right colour
steps.description: Most energy efficient bulbs are available as warm white or cool white.
steps.read_more:
Warm white bulbs give out light that’s the same colour as traditional filament bulbs. If you want to fit energy efficient bulbs without changing the feel of your home, then choose warm white.

Cool white bulbs give out light that is a bit less yellow. The whiter light can create a colder appearance, but some people prefer this.

Some bulbs are also available in a daylight option. These give out pure white light that matches the colour of actual daylight. They are usually used for specific purposes – such as when people need to compare colours accurately as part of their work.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: LEDs and CFLs of various fittings are widely available in DIY or home stores and can also be found in most local supermarkets. You can also find lights for virtually every use by searching online. Make sure you buy the right fitting. When replacing a bulb it is a good idea to take the old bulb to the shop with you, so you can compare fittings.

steps.headline: Using your low energy lighting
steps.description: You can save more money by being conscious about how you use your lighting. Follow the tips below.
steps.read_more:
• Always turn your lights off when you leave a room, even if just for a minute
• Be conscious of how many lights you have on and whether you need them all on
• Use a sensor to control external lights so they are only on when they need to be
• When the wiring is being done, you should arrange your light switches so that it is convenient to turn them off. For example, at the top and bottom of stairs, each end of a hallway or each door to a room

acf.headline: Draught-proof your windows and doors
acf.summary: Sealing the unwanted gaps around your doors and windows will help keep the heat in, and will cut down on cold draughts throughout your home.

advantages.advantage: Can be DIY or get a professional
Can be done one window at a time

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Sealing the unwanted gaps around your doors and windows will help keep the heat in, and will cut down on cold draughts throughout your home.
steps.read_more:
Every external door and every opening window in your home has a gap round the edge that should seal tight when the door or window is fully closed. If the seal isn’t good enough, then cold air can blow in through the gap, and warm air can blow out. Old or badly fitted windows can have gaps around the frame or glass even if they don’t open, and doors can have extra gaps around a letter box, cat flap or keyhole.

This will increase your heating bills, because all the money you spent heating this air up is wasted as soon as the air leaks out. You will also feel less comfortable in a draughty house, because the cold air feels even colder if it is blowing through the room.

Draught-proofing an existing door or window is fairly straightforward, provided you use the right materials for each job. You can either pay a professional to choose the right products and fit them correctly, or you can buy your own and fit them yourself.

Draught-proofing is different to double glazing, and it does a different job. Double glazing is designed to stop heat escaping through the glass itself. Draught-proofing is designed to stop heat escaping through gaps around the edges.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: Unless your house is very new, you probably have some draughts somewhere in the house, and it may be worth doing something to control them.
steps.read_more:
Generally speaking, the older a door or window the more likely it is to have a draught problem. A new window or outside door ought to seal well and be pretty much free from draughts. But even a new door or window can be draughty if it is poor quality or has not been fitted well.

If your house is very draughty you will know this just from feeling draughts in the house, especially when the weather is cold and windy. You can walk round the house holding your hand against each edge of every window to work out where the draughts are coming from.

If you have draughts then you will save energy by blocking them off, but….
• You shouldn’t block off any deliberate ventilation such as air bricks and wall vents – they were put there for a reason.
• If you have a condensation problem in a room, then you need to sort that out before blocking off any draughts in that room. If you can fix the condensation by producing less water (e.g. not drying clothes in that room) or by increasing your controlled ventilation (e.g. turning the extractor fan on more often) then you could then try fixing any uncontrolled draughts.

steps.headline: How to get it
steps.description: Draught-proofing is relatively straightforward to do if you are confident at DIY, but there are plenty of professionals who can do it for you.
steps.read_more:
If you want to fit draught-proofing yourself, then you can get a wide range of products and materials at any good DIY store. Two things to remember:
• Make sure you’re buying the right product for the job. If you have a sash window, for example, you need to buy a draught-proofing kit specifically for sash windows.
• Follow the instructions – some systems are obvious but others are more complicated.

Most DIY shops will give advice on which products to buy and how to fit them.

If you would like to use a professional, see the following link.

acf.headline: Floor insulation (for a solid floor)
acf.summary: Adding insulation to an existing solid floor is not straightforward, but it will help you make sure your whole house is keeping the heat in.

advantages.advantage: Often overlooked when insulating a house

steps.headline: What it is
steps.description: Adding insulation to an existing solid floor not straightforward, but it will help you make sure your whole house is keeping the heat in.
steps.read_more:
If your house has a solid concrete floor, then there are two ways it can be insulated.

It may be possible to add a layer of rigid insulation board on top of the existing concrete, with a layer of boarding on top of that to create a new floor level. You will lose some headroom, and you will have to move or adjust skirting boards, doors, any fitted cupboards, and maybe electrical sockets or plumbing.

The alternative is to dig out the existing concrete, dig down further and add a new damp-proof membrane, a layer of rigid insulation and a new concrete screed or other flooring. This is an expensive and disruptive job, and is usually carried out as part of a major refurbishment project, or when there is a problem with the existing floor.

If you have an old solid floor made of stone flags or similar, then the best way to insulate it is to remove the flagstones, dig down and add a membrane, insulation and screed, before re-laying the stones. This is a big task, but it has the advantage of adding a damp-proof layer which probably wasn’t there before.

steps.headline: Is it right for me?
steps.description: If the ground floor of your house is made of a solid concrete slab, or flagstones or similar, with no air gap underneath, then you may want to consider solid floor insulation.
steps.read_more:
Some houses have a ground floor that is built of horizontal timber joists, with floor boards or other boarding over the top, and a gap underneath. Other houses have a concrete slab, or flag stones, quarry tiles or similar, sitting directly on the ground with no air gap beneath. If there is no air gap then you have a solid floor.

If the house was built after 1995 then it probably has some insulation already built into it. If not, you may want to consider insulating your solid floors.

Insulating a solid floor requires a lot of work, and can cause significant disruption in the home. You may want to consider insulating a solid floor at a time when you are doing major work in that room anyway.

If your ground floor is a timber floor with an air gap underneath, then this is called a suspended floor, and is much easier to insulate.

steps.description: You will need a professional installer to insulate a solid floor. The installer will generally provide all the materials.
